segments.text: which was a pilot in Vietnam.
And what was your date of birth?
September 17th, 1944.
Okay, and you were a pilot.
Okay, what we're doing is going to begin an interview concerning the war in Vietnam that he is a veteran of.
Okay, the first kind of question, and of course you can stop me and go anywhere you like, is I'd first like to know about your life prior to Vietnam.
What were your plans before Vietnam, and what would you have been doing at that time if Vietnam did not occur?
My dad was career military.
He was in the Signal Corps and retired in 1964 as Lieutenant Colonel.
I went to the University of Texas at El Paso.
It was Texas Western, then it became UT El Paso, and was in ROTC and completed my ROTC requirements prior, about a year prior to graduation.
And it was because there was a high demand for officers and pilots.
They offered me a commission prior to graduation, which fortunately I declined and went ahead and finished my degree.
At the same time that they were offering me the commission, I got married in November of 66, graduated in January of 68, and had to report in April of 68 to Fort Gordon, Georgia,
because I had chosen my basic branch, Signal Corps.
The Army at that time did not have an aviation branch.
They needed you to have a basic branch, and I chose Signal Corps because that's what my dad was in and that's what I knew.
We went to California for a couple of months until it was time to report and worked at Greyhound.
in the bagging department, making more money than I made as a second lieutenant when I reported for active duty.
But we went to Fort Gordon.
I was there from April until the end of July.
And in August, actually end of July, first of August, I reported to Fort Stewart, Georgia for the first phase of flight school.
And I was initial entry fixed wing
which meant airplanes as opposed to helicopters.
Helicopters are rotary wings.
That's how we refer to those.
The first phase of flight school was four months in Fort Stewart, learning how to fly T-41s, their little Cessna 182s, high-wing fixed-gear aircraft.
And then we went to Fort Rucker, Alabama,
In December, for the second four months of flight school, we had a little break in between.
And there I learned to fly the T-42, which is a beach baron for instrument training.
And then the bird dog, which is also a Cessna high-wing observation plane.
Are you familiar with the bird dog?
A little bit.
Okay.
Pilot sits in the front.
Observer or instructor sits in the back.
Tail wheel.
And we learned how to operate that in what they call a tactical plane.
means and tactical method.
A lot of low level flying, a lot of short field.
So more of a combat.
More of a preparing us for what they thought we would do in Vietnam.
Turns out it wasn't that much.
We would practice firing artillery and things like that.
The artillery was the only thing that they taught us in that phase that was really useful.
But that's basically the way the training went until May of 69, end of April, actually, first of May.
And you get a little leave, and we went to California to see my parents.
They live in Los Angeles.
And then in early May, I left for Vietnam out of San Francisco.
In 69?
In 69.
Now, that is where I'll leave off for a moment en route to Vietnam.
You asked what I would be doing if I hadn't gone there.
It never entered my mind that I would not go.
Oh, really?
I had planned on being in the military from before I entered college.
Spending some time, I didn't know if I was going to make it a career or not, but I planned on spending some time in the military.
I planned early on to take
ROTC, and since Vietnam was going on before I entered, or about the time I entered college, they were starting to build up and stuff like that, it just seemed logical that I would go over there.
There was no concern or anticipation or anything special.
I just accepted that I would serve and
high probability that that's where I would serve, one of the places I would serve, so it was no big deal.
What was your age when you... Let's see, when I went in the Army in 68, I turned 24 in September of 68, so I was a little less than 24 when I entered the military.
I was about 24 and a half when I left for Vietnam.
Did you feel that that was comparatively older or younger?
I didn't know at the time, but I felt that that was about average.
It turns out that if you take the vast bulk of the people who served there, it was actually a little older.
An awful lot of the troops were around 19.
And you can't say that the average age was 19, but
large number were in the 18 and 19 year category.

We even had officers, pilots who were warrant officers and we had commissioned officers who were infantry who'd gone through OCS basic training and officer candidate school who were very young, 20 and 21 years old.
So we had a pretty young force.
What type of mental
and or physical preparations did you make before leaving to go to Vietnam and were there any medical?
Well you had to get a battery of shots and they put us on medication for malaria as a preventative.
Pilots couldn't take everything that everybody else could.
We had quinine is one of the preventatives and it
enhances your tendency towards vertigo.
So we couldn't take that, but we took all the other shots and we didn't do any special physical activities or anything like that.
Had I had it to do over again, we would have.
The pilots, they didn't feel needed to do that.
We did escape and evasion courses and we did physical training tests, but not to the extent that the Army does now.
Right.
nor to the extent that I would recommend.
Mental preparation, really, again, you learn by doing.
I feel that there could have been a little bit more in the way of information from people who had served as to what you go through mentally once you get there.
And it may be different for everybody, so maybe they can't do that, but
I would have liked to have had a little better feel for what a pilot doing the kind of mission that I was going to do would go through.
The problem with that is that they don't really know where you're going to go exactly until you get there and start in processing, and we'll get into that later, I'm sure.
Okay.
What was your general feeling towards the government and military before and after?
Well, my father's parents came from Soviet Armenia,
When he was in the Army, we lived in Germany right after World War II in 1950.
Well, not right after World War II, but 1955, 1956.
And we knew people who had escaped from East Germany.
When we lived in Taiwan, I went to high school my sophomore and junior years in Taipei, Taiwan.
And we knew people who had escaped from Red China.
These were not malcontents or people who were on the dole.
but successful professionals under the communist systems.
And they gave up the easy life to get out of there and experience freedom.
So having come from that background, you might consider me somewhat patriotic and very supportive of the government.
I also have very strong feelings about communism that were borne out, not changed by my service in Vietnam.
Those people do things as a matter of policy that are, I think, less than human.
And so I had no qualms at all about fighting them at that time.
This is getting ahead a little bit, but on reflection,
If we had to do over again, I would rather have a policy where we were fighting to win and where we were staying for the duration instead of a one-year tour of duty because we would have won.
People will contradict me on that, but we had the war won after 10 of 68.
We had them decimated.
They were on their knees, and we could have taken them out.
We gave them sanctuaries.
both in North Vietnam at times, definitely from ground incursions.
And they operated freely in Cambodia and Laos.
And we operated there, but with constraints.
And so we could have beaten them, but we had no intention.
The Johnson administration had no intention of winning the war.
They didn't know how to run a war.

They tried to micromanage from the White House tactical targets and had the Vietnam War been operated like World War II was in Europe under Eisenhower when he was given the command to invade the continent of Europe and defeat the enemy.
And that was the sum total of his mission.
That's all the interference that he got from Washington.
And the way Bush ran
Desert Storm, and we turned it over to the military, we could have won.
The way it was won was terrible, terrible.
The way it was run was a terrible waste.
And it was almost criminal the way some of the lives were squandered in Vietnam.
And I find that I'll never, never forgive the administration at that time.
By the time Nixon took over, there was no
nothing to do but get out.
The only question was, how do you get out?
And so by that time, the die was cast and we had to leave under some form or another without trying to win.
Did I answer that question?
Yes, you did.
Did you hear or know of people protesting the war before you were sent?
What was your reaction or what would have been your reaction if you hadn't?
If you didn't hear about it before, what...
I did hear about it before, and I... All war is immoral.
I mean, there's no such thing as a good war.
You might say World War II came close, but even it was...
It could have been avoided had the Allies stood up to Hitler prior to his...
conquest of Poland, etc.
So, war is not a good answer.
I've been a student of history since I was in junior high.
I read extensively about the Civil War, World War I and World War II, as well as some of our minor efforts, the Spanish-American War, etc.,
And the first thing that struck me in junior high and high school was the terrible waste of war, of materiel and resources, but especially fine, fine people.
I mean, that would be productive members of society, but they don't have that opportunity because they're killed or maimed.
So I have been opposed to war all my life.
I have felt, however, there are times that it's necessary and you do it.
And I felt that at the time and still do that communism is an intolerable government style.
And it was opposed to us.
They had declared war on us.
And I felt that we had to do that.
The protesters, therefore, I felt were either misguided, short-sighted, or malicious.
And I did oppose and would have opposed those protesters, but then they've got the right to say what they want to.
So as long as we're a free country, we shouldn't be afraid of ideas that are different than ours.
The protests did wind up having an effect on me that I guess we'll get into later on.
Okay, what part or what dates actually were you in Vietnam?
How long were you there?
Well, I left on May 5th, which started my clock ticking, May 5th of 69.
And I went to the Philippines first for jungle survival school for a week.
So I spent the first week in the Philippines.
And then I went to Vietnam and went into Saigon and reported to the 90th Replacement Depot.
at Long Bend.
And all they do is they start a pipeline, and they sort of feed you through the pipeline.
And whoever has the greatest need gets those people to come in.
So I had no clue where I was going.
And the next thing they did was they sent me to the 17th Group, which was part of the 1st Aviation Brigade.
And the 17th Group was located at Nha Trang.
and they'd say there's a plane leaving such and such a time beyond it, and I'd just show my orders and get on the plane and go.
Went into Natrang and spent the night there after in-processing with the 17th group, again, not knowing where I was going.
That night, I was sleeping in the top bunk of the top floor of a wooden barracks and heard a noise, and it woke me up.
I was a very light sleeper all my life, and it woke me up,
And nobody else was moving, and I didn't want to be the rookie on the block because there were veterans there who were out processing too.
So I started to lay back down, and mortar rounds started going off.
And I looked around, and I was all by myself.
Everybody else was gone just that fast.
So I put some boots on and went out in the bunker, and by that time it was all over.
And they didn't land all that close, so there was no real danger, but it was amazing how
What I had heard was the sound of the mortar going down the tube and being fired.
And then the explosions after that is what got everybody else's attention.
But the next day, I left Nha Trang and went to Quy Nhon, where I was processed into the 223rd Aviation Battalion, which is a primarily fixed-wing battalion.
And they sent me to Dong Ba Tin, which is across the bay from Cam Ranh Bay.
to the 183rd Reconnaissance Airplane Company, because I knew I was going to fly bird dogs.
That was the only thing I'd been cleared to fly.
And that's a bird dog company.
And they gave me an in-processing that lasted about a week.
So I'd been gone from the States about three weeks when I finally got sent down to Fanthiet, which was the home of the second flight platoon.
of the 183rd reconnaissance airplane company.
And Fanthiet is on the coast.
It was an ideal location.
It was 90 miles due east of Saigon, 90 miles south of Cameron.
We were sort of left alone by our higher headquarters as long as we did our job.
And I stayed there the entire year.
So it was about a year and three weeks or just a year and two?
Well, I was there a year and a day.
When we talk about out-processing, I'll tell you a little bit about that, too.
So, going in, they kind of gave you, you mentioned before, a week in the jungle.
Was that actually on the ground?
Yes.
Learning how to...
They gave us a lot of instruction on escape and evasion.

and survival tactics in case we got shot down and we were going to be flying primarily over jungle and not entirely as it turned out for me because I was on the coastal plain and then the highlands also and a little triple canopy jungle there but they would tell us how to avoid the enemy what to do assuming you survived the crash what was the first thing you did what was the second thing you did how to get water
how to determine if something was edible.

We would open a palm tree and eat the hearts of palm right out of the palm tree and catch water moisture that travels down palm leaves at night because it's so humid it condenses on them when it cools and things like that.
The checkout in country was how to fire the rockets and a
recheck on communications procedures and artillery procedures.

Do you remember, I guess you had mentioned before, you kind of felt like the whole time you were going, you were going to go to Vietnam, but did it shock you at all when you really got the news that you were actually going over there at the time of day?
No, the only thing that was disappointing was further training
once you completed flight school, was determined by your standing in your class in your branch.
You had all these different branches, and I was sonocore.
And I was number one in my class in my branch.
And my branch had a slot for OV-1s, which is the Mohawk, which is a much more sophisticated, large, twin-engine, turbine-powered aircraft.
Really a hot, hot thing to fly.
And so that was my slot.
But the class leader who had seniority on me and who had been on the ground in Vietnam for a year and had just gotten back had not yet had a full year back in Vietnam.
So in order to extend him before he went back over there, they gave him the Mohawk slot, which stuck me in bird dogs.
As it turns out, whereas I would have enjoyed flying Mohawks, I had such an interesting time.
I got to see so many different things.
by flying bird dogs.
I would have been bored in Mohawks.
And it turned out it was the right thing for me.
So it didn't, I mean I was expecting the orders and it didn't bother me.
Do you feel that there were other attitudes than yours?
Do you feel like your attitude was unique before going to Vietnam?
How did the other men feel?
I don't know.
I think probably about the same.
What you have to understand is
But that was a 10 year war.
So there was a lot of room for different attitudes over time.
At any one time, at the height of the build up, there was 500,000 US troops in and around Vietnam.
A lot of different people with different attitudes.
There were different branches of the service, Air Force, Army, Navy, Marines.
There were different branches within the Army.
There were all these different assignments and units.
And yet you could have two people at the same unit at the same time experiencing the same thing come away with two different impressions of what happened.
So anything I say, you have to take with a grain of salt.
And therefore, I can't speak for anybody else, really.
I can tell you what some people did or said, but I can't get inside their head.
And I don't think I was all that unusual.
I know a lot of people who were looking forward to going there.
either for their career enhancement or because they felt about communism the way I did, or because of the...
I had one NCO when I was in training.
We were learning how to fire mortars in Officer's Basic.
And he'd been there three times and was trying to go back again.
He'd been wounded once.
He still wanted to go back.
And he was a young, still young,
black NCO, non-commissioned officer, sergeant.
And he said, I want to go back again because that's where the action is.
This is my profession.
That's where my profession is being practiced.
And a lot of guys are that way.
When you arrived in Vietnam, were you surprised by anything?
If so, what were they?
Or were you expecting everything you saw?
What were some of the things that stick out in your mind about the way people lived, the land itself, or the general culture?
Well, it had a smell that was different.
A lot of the address of the women were different, and some of the men, too.
They did wear pajamas a lot.
The black pajamas.
Yeah.
I had seen enough films, et cetera, that the countryside was what I expected.
I had lived in Taiwan, so I expected the heat and humidity, and that wasn't a surprise.
I guess the only thing, when I finally got down to Fanfayette, got assigned to the second flight platoon, the way they do call signs is each platoon has a call sign.
Actually, each company has a call sign.
And our company call sign was Seahorse.
So when you go to the second flight platoon, your call sign is Seahorse to something.
The 6 always designates the commander, so the platoon leader is Seahorse 2-6.
The company commander would be Seahorse 6.
The second flight platoon commander would be Seahorse 2-6.
I was Seahorse 2-2.
You don't say 22, you say 2-2.
Well, when I got there, the fellow who had had that call sign before me
had been, I was replacing him, he was shot down and killed about two weeks before.

And the first thing they told us was that we had a lot of missions, reconnaissance missions in the mountains, in this triple canopy jungle area, and that we couldn't go in there single ship because it was too far and too dangerous.
And all of a sudden, I thought, you know, this might be a little dangerous.
and I might not survive this.

And for a while, I thought that I was scared for about the first couple of months because about a month after I got there, they said, we've got too many missions and too few pilots and planes, and now you've got to fly in the mountains in a single ship with nobody to back you up.
And so it was...
All of a sudden, I didn't feel quite so well prepared and so well trained.
And I was, you know, when I left, my son was nine months old, and I had always felt sort of invulnerable.
When I was in high school and college, you know, I thought nothing could touch me.
I drove my car fast, and I had my first crash in an airplane.
It was in ROTC flight training there in El Paso.
My second crash was in flight school.
A guy, another student, was riding the front seat and I was sitting in the back.
And he put a wing into the ground and very nearly cartwheeled us and killed us.
And we got out of that and he almost put us in the trees on the way out.
I had a near midair with him flying in the front seat.
He's called his stick buddy, and he's a warrant officer candidate.
He's a good pilot.
He just had some mental lapses every now and then.
We almost hit a helicopter one day.
So none of those things bothered me.
The crashes didn't bother me while they were going on.
It didn't bother me after they were over.
For some reason, it just didn't affect me.
But flying into those mountains by myself after the guy before me had been killed, that's sort of unsettling.
And I felt a little vulnerable at that time.
And it wasn't until later that your attitude changes, at least mine did.
So I was a little rattled there, of course.
Could you describe an average day, if there was one?
What times did you do things?
Where were you?
Well, I was in Fanthia, and at first I lived out at what we called the landing zone, or LZ.
It was an airfield, a pure steel planking runway.
And we had a hangar there, and some revetments made out of 50-gallon oil drums, 55-gallon drums filled with sand.
We parked the aircraft in to protect them from mortar attacks and things like that.
And I'd get up before dawn in the morning and get cleaned up.
We had...
cold water showers.
At least we had showers every day.
But they were cold water, and I don't care how hot it is, a cold shower is a cold shower.
And we wore Nomex flight suits, which is, they're fire retardant flight suits, and we were pretty heavily armed.
We put on our, I wore a .45 pistol and a holster, and we had to have a canteen with you when you fly.
We'd have an M16.
I'd have a survival vest, and on top of the survival vest, the survival vest wasn't flotation.
It had a survival radio and all the stuff you need to operate in the jungle, a fishing line and a signal mirror and a survival radio and a net and just a whole bunch of stuff.
And then I'd wear two bandoliers of M16 ammunition with these clips, magazines.
and an M16 and a flight helmet.
So I was pretty weighted down by the time.
And you'd have a morning mission and an afternoon mission.
And every so often we'd throw in a noon mission just so you could keep guessing as to when you were going to fly over their area because all we were trying to do was spot them.
They were hiding from us and we were trying to find them.
And you'd have a mission in support of some unit
or some operation or another.
We would fly in support of the Navy.

They'd send cruisers and destroyers up and down the coast, and they'd get into our province, and we'd put an air-naval gunfire liaison or Anglico enlisted man or officer in the back seat and go out and fire missions with these naval ships.
So I got to see how the Navy operated.
And mainly what they did was they fired into...
three fire zones at bogus targets.
I mean, we blew up the same hooch in the same bunker all year.

You know, you had to call in a gun damage assessment or GDA just to justify the expenditure of the rounds, but we blew up more bushes than you can shake a stick at firing these expensive rounds at them.
It's not entirely wasted, however, because what it does is it
tells the enemy that you just can't operate with impunity in this free fire zone, that we're going to at least give you a headache and a bloody nose if we don't kill you.
So the Navy was one mission.
Artillery was another.
Artillery batteries had to be registered.
And so we had various registration points.
We'd go out and fire registration.
Visual reconnaissance was another.
We'd go out and look for signs of the enemy.
And if we found them, we'd call in
whatever we could, gunships, artillery, reaction forces, depends on how many we found.
I flew in support of an outfit called the Second of the First Cav, Second Squadron First Cav.
They had a cavalry as tanks and APCs, armored personnel carriers.
And they have a Delta Troop, which is gunships, the AH-1 Cobra gunships.
I flew in support of the 192nd Assault Helicopter Company and their gun platoon, which was what we called Charlie Model, UH-1C gunships.
Flew in support of the...
